title.value: GRAPH TEXT: GRAPH REASONING IN TEXT SPACE
title.justification: The title of the research paper that includes information on the presented framework and its purpose.
title.quote: GRAPH TEXT: GRAPH REASONING IN TEXT SPACE

extractions.description: The paper introduces GRAPH TEXT, a novel framework designed to convert graph data to natural language format to facilitate reasoning via Large Language Models (LLMs). GRAPH TEXT constructs a graph-syntax tree for each graph capturing node attributes and inter-node relationships. By transforming graph tasks into text generation tasks, GRAPH TEXT enables training-free and interactive graph reasoning.

type.justification: The paper presents empirical results demonstrating the effectiveness of the GRAPH TEXT framework on various graph machine learning tasks.
type.quote: We conduct extensive experiments to demonstrate the effectiveness of GRAPH TEXT.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on improving graph machine learning tasks by leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs).
name.quote: However, despite their impressive achievements, LLMs have not made significant advancements in the realm of graph machine learning.

name.justification: The paper seeks to bridge the gap between graphs and natural language, transforming graph data into text sequences for LLMs.
name.quote: In this paper, we bridge this gap with a novel framework, GRAPH TEXT, that translates graphs to natural language.

name.justification: GRAPH TEXT enables interactive graph reasoning, allowing direct interaction with both humans and other LLMs using natural language.
name.quote: GRAPH TEXT paves the way for interactive graph reasoning, allowing both humans and LLMs to communicate with the model seamlessly using natural language.

name.justification: GRAPH TEXT is the main model introduced in the paper for transforming graphs into natural language.
name.quote: In this paper, we bridge this gap with a novel framework, GRAPH TEXT, that translates graphs to natural language.

is_contributed.justification: GRAPH TEXT is introduced and developed within the scope of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: In this paper, we bridge this gap with a novel framework, GRAPH TEXT, that translates graphs to natural language.

is_executed.justification: GRAPH TEXT is executed using LLMs such as ChatGPT and GPT-4 for various tasks.
is_executed.quote: GRAPH TEXT with ChatGPT can achieve on par with, or even surpassing, the performance of supervised-trained graph neural networks.

is_compared.justification: GRAPH TEXT is compared with other approaches including state-of-the-art GNNs and other ICL baselines.
is_compared.quote: The experimental findings reveal that methods using the raw graph as a prompt, such as NeighborText, GML, GraphML, and GRAPH TEXT ot+or, exhibit subpar performance. However, the incorporation of graph inductive bias into both synthetic text attributes and relations leads to significant performance improvements across all datasets.

referenced_paper_title.justification: GRAPH TEXT is introduced and referenced within this paper and no external referenced paper is associated with it.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We bridge this gap with a novel framework, GRAPH TEXT, that translates graphs to natural language.

name.justification: Cora is used for evaluating the performance of GRAPH TEXT in node classification tasks.
name.quote: Specifically, we use two citation datasets (Cora and Citeseer), and three webpage datasets (Texas, Wisconsin, and Cornell).

referenced_paper_title.value: Automating the Construction of Internet Portals with Machine Learning
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper provides the initial dataset of Cora that is used in this research for evaluating GRAPH TEXT.
referenced_paper_title.quote: C. L. Giles, K. D. Bollacker, and S. Lawrence, “Automating the construction of Internet portals with machine learning,” Information Retrieval, 2000.

name.justification: Citeseer is used for evaluating the performance of GRAPH TEXT in node classification tasks.
name.quote: Specifically, we use two citation datasets (Cora and Citeseer), and three webpage datasets (Texas, Wisconsin, and Cornell).

referenced_paper_title.quote: C. Lee Giles, Kurt D. Bollacker, and Steve Lawrence. Citeseer: An automatic citation indexing system. In ACM DL 1998.

referenced_paper_title.quote: H. Pei, B. Wei, K.-C. Chang, Y. Lei, and B. Yang, “Geom-GCN: Geometric graph convolutional networks,” in ICLR, 2020.

name.justification: ChatGPT is one of the LLMs used in the experiments with the GRAPH TEXT model.
name.quote: Remarkably, even without training on graph data, GRAPH TEXT with ChatGPT can deliver performance on par with, or even surpassing, supervised graph neural networks through in-context learning.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This blog post provides details about the ChatGPT model referenced in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: OpenAI. Introducing ChatGPT. OpenAI, 2023. URL: https://openai.com/blog/chatgpt
